title: Is there a greatest common factor?
Is the polynomial a binomial, trinomial, or are there more than three terms?
Trinomial
text: Since it's a trinomial, check to see whether the expression is in the form of $$x^2+bx+x$$ or $${ax}^2+bx+c$$
speech: Since it's a trinomial, check to see whether the expression is in the form of  x squared plus b x plus, x  or  a x squared plus b x plus c
pacedSpeech: Since it's a trinomial, check to see whether the expression is in the form of   x squared plus b x plus, x
or   a x squared plus b x plus c

title: $${ax}^2+bx+c$$
text: Since a and c are squares, check if it fits the trinomial square pattern
speech: Since a and c are squares, check if it fits the trinomial square pattern
pacedSpeech: Since a and c are squares, check if it fits the trinomial square pattern

title: Trinomial square pattern
text: The expression fits the square pattern $${\left(a-b\right)}^2=a^2-2ab+b^2$$
speech: The expression fits the square pattern  parentheses a minus b,  squared is equal to a squared minus 2 a b, plus b squared
pacedSpeech: The expression fits the square pattern    a minus b,  squared is equal to a squared minus 2 a b, plus b squared

title: Check
text: Is it factored completely? Do the factors multiply back to the original polynomial?
speech: Is it factored completely? Do the factors multiply back to the original polynomial?
pacedSpeech: Is it factored completely? Do the factors multiply back to the original polynomial?
